pullrequest.title: Support frame semantics in for models nested with <include>

content.raw:
What about any element that has a pose element? e.g. `//visual`, `//collision`, sensors?

Should all of those be iterated through?
content.html:
What about any element that has a pose element? e.g. //visual, //collision, sensors?

Should all of those be iterated through?

pullrequest.title: Support frame semantics in for models nested with <include>

content.raw: Poses in `//visual` and `//collision` using `__model__` as their relative_to were not being handled. Instead of iterating through all of those, I'm using the replace mechanism to replace all instances of `__model__` with `<model_name>::__model__`. b49fffe
content.html: Poses in //visual and //collision using __model__ as their relative_to were not being handled. Instead of iterating through all of those, I'm using the replace mechanism to replace all instances of __model__ with <model_name>::__model__. b49fffe

pullrequest.title: Support frame semantics in for models nested with <include>

content.raw:
Per f2f, there could be a bug where collision names might be renamed to the nested name accidentally.

e.g. in included model “mid\_model”, we have link name “a”, with collision name “a”.

Correct behavior \(for merging approach\) would be to have “mid\_model::a”, with collision “a”.

Current text replacement will have link “mid\_model::a” with collision “mid\_model::a”, which is a bug, but minor.

Could also have issues where a link is named “fixed”, and then joint types get replaced…
content.html:
Per f2f, there could be a bug where collision names might be renamed to the nested name accidentally.

e.g. in included model “mid_model”, we have link name “a”, with collision name “a”.

Correct behavior (for merging approach) would be to have “mid_model::a”, with collision “a”.

Current text replacement will have link “mid_model::a” with collision “mid_model::a”, which is a bug, but minor.

Could also have issues where a link is named “fixed”, and then joint types get replaced…

content.raw: It's been a while so I'm not 100%, but I originally thought I would use the `#` as a token to ignore the comment when reading the file in (as opposed to just ignoring the first line). I think I can use xml comments for this and it'll be fine, albeit not a strictly valid xml because `<?xml...` has to be on the very first line for valid xml.
content.html: It's been a while so I'm not 100%, but I originally thought I would use the # as a token to ignore the comment when reading the file in (as opposed to just ignoring the first line). I think I can use xml comments for this and it'll be fine, albeit not a strictly valid xml because <?xml... has to be on the very first line for valid xml.
